name.text: 29.2.3.11 Vector field div dot prod surface Integral

questiontext.text:
Evaluate the integral \(\displaystyle \iint_S \underline{\nabla}\phi \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S}\) for \(\phi = {@x^aa * z^bb@} \sin y\) and \(S\) being the rectangle bounded by \((0, 0, 0)\), \((1, 0, 1)\), \((1, \pi, 1)\) and \((0, \pi, 0)\).

generalfeedback.text:
We aim to evaluate the integral \(\displaystyle \iint_S \underline{\nabla}\phi \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S}\) for \(\phi = {@x^aa*z^bb@} \sin y\) and \(S\) being the rectangle bounded by \((0, 0, 0)\), \((1, 0, 1)\), \((1, \pi, 1)\) and \((0, \pi, 0)\).

We first aim to find the vector \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S}\). Firstly, we can chose two perpendicular vectors inside the rectangle, and take their cross product to find the normal vector, let \(\underline{u} = \underline{j}\), \(\underline{v} = \underline{i} + \underline{k}\), then: \[ \begin{aligned} \underline{u} \times \underline{v} &= \begin{vmatrix} \underline{i} & \underline{j} & \underline{k}\\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \end{vmatrix}\\ &= ((1)(1)- (0)(0))\underline{i} - ((0)(1) - (0)(1))\underline{j} + ((0)(0) - (1)(1))\underline{k}\\ &= \underline{i} - \underline{k}\\ &\text{now calculating }\underline{\hat{n}}\\ \underline{\hat{n}}&= \frac{\underline{i} - \underline{k}}{\sqrt{1^2+1^2}}\\ &= \frac{\underline{i}}{\sqrt{2}} - \frac{\underline{k}}{\sqrt{2}}. \end{aligned} \] Now the area of this rectangle is \(A_1 = \sqrt{2}\pi\), the area of its projection onto the \(y-z\) plane is: \(A_2 = \pi\). Therefore we find \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} = \dfrac{A_1}{A_2}\underline{\hat{n}} \mathrm{d}y\mathrm{d}z = (\underline{i} - \underline{k})\mathrm{d}y\mathrm{d}z.\)

Now we can find the bounds of the double integral. The outer integral has upper bound \(z= 1\) and lower bound \(z=0\). The inner integral has upper bound \(y= \pi\) and lower bound \(y=0\). Therefore we can calculate the the surface integral as follows (bearing in mind that \(x=z\) due to the original rectangle lying in the said plane)): \[ \begin{aligned} \iint_S \underline{\nabla}\phi \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} &= \iint_S \left[ ({@diffi@})\underline{i} + ({@diffj@})\underline{j} + ({@diffk@})\underline{k}\right]\cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S}\\ &=\int^{z= 1}_{z= 0} \int^{y= \pi}_{y=0} \left[ ({@diffi@})\underline{i} + ({@diffj@})\underline{j} + ({@diffk@})\underline{k}\right] \cdot \left[\underline{i} - \underline{k}\right]\ \mathrm{d}y\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= \int^{z= 1}_{z= 0} \int^{y= \pi}_{y=0} {@expres2@}\ \mathrm{d}y\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= \int^{z= 1}_{z= 0} \left[{@First_int_indef@}\right]^{y= \pi}_{y=0}\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &=\int^{z= 1}_{z= 0} {@First_int_def@}\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &=\left[{@Second_int_indef@}\right]^{z= 1}_{z= 0}\\ &= {@Second_int_def@} \end{aligned} \]
